content.description: Start on the inclined, sloping, crimp rail. Move up and left using the sloping aerie and face crimps to the topout.
content.location: The downclimb is on the northeast corner.

content.description:
Sit start on the big ledge. Move up using a good hold to a crimp rail and a sloping ledge rail. From there, pop up to the top. This is the same ending as

Navajo Bat Mitzvah

.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter. It is not a good landing, but it's navigable.
content.location: The downclimb is on the northeast corner of the boulder.

content.description: This is just me, but this is an instant classic. Start on an sloping, angled rail. Move right through crimps, mono-pockets, and more crimps before you get to the sloping rail. Once there, pop to the top for an easy topout.
content.protection: Pads are necessary. It's not a great landing, and it would be good to have a good spotter as well.
content.location: On the South side of the Dippin' Dots Block, start on the left-center side. The downclimb is on the northeast corner.

content.description:
This is a sweet compression problem up the southwest arete of the Dippin' Dots Block.

Start on the let side and move up using crimps and sidepulls over a sketchy landing. Move right as you begin to compress and move to the top.
content.protection: Pads and GREAT spotters. The landing is awful.
content.location: It is on the Southwest corner of Dippin' Dots Block. There is an easy downclimb on the northeast corner.

content.description: Start with two glorious right hand and left hand sidepulls. The difficult part is that they are a body length away from each other so you're super compressed into the face. Get a left foot on a sloping ledge, and move to the obvious rail of sidepulls and ledges. The topout is good as long as it hasn't rained or snowed, as it accumulates in the dishes you'll want to top out with.
content.protection: Pads. The landing isn't perfect, but it's motivation to send.
content.location: This is on the north face of the boulder in the direct center. There is a downclimb on the northeast corner where you can climb down to another boulder and descend.
